What's wrong with using index as key in React?

Using array index as key causes bugs when items can be reordered, inserted, or deleted.

**The problem:** React uses keys to track which items changed. If you use index as key, and you insert an item at position 0:

```
Before: [A(key=0), B(key=1), C(key=2)]
Insert X at start:
After:  [X(key=0), A(key=1), B(key=2), C(key=3)]
```

React thinks: key=0 changed from A→X, key=1 changed from B→A, key=2 changed from C→B, and key=3 is new. So it re-renders EVERY item and destroys/recreates their state. With proper keys:

```
Before: [A(key=a), B(key=b), C(key=c)]
After:  [X(key=x), A(key=a), B(key=b), C(key=c)]
```

React knows A, B, C are unchanged — just insert X. One DOM operation instead of four.

**Real bugs this causes:**
- Input fields lose their text (component state destroyed)
- Animations replay on items that didn't change
- Focus jumps to wrong element
- Expensive components re-mount unnecessarily

**When index IS safe:** Static lists that never reorder, insert, or delete. Like rendering a fixed navigation menu.

**What to use instead:**
```jsx
// Use a stable unique ID from your data
items.map(item => <Card key={item.id} {...item} />)

// If no ID exists, generate one when creating the item
const newItem = { id: crypto.randomUUID(), text: input };
```

Rule: if the list can change, use a stable ID. If it's truly static, index is fine but ID is still safer.

Getting CORS error when calling my API from localhost

CORS errors happen when your frontend (localhost:3000) tries to call a different origin (your API at localhost:8000 or api.example.com). The browser blocks it for security.

**The fix is on the SERVER, not the client.** The server needs to include CORS headers in its response.

**If your API is Express/Node:**
```javascript
const cors = require('cors');
app.use(cors({ origin: 'http://localhost:3000' }));
```

**If your API is Next.js API route:**
Already same-origin — CORS shouldn't happen. If it does, you're probably calling the wrong URL (hitting your production API from localhost).

**If you don't control the server:**
Use a proxy. In Next.js, add to `next.config.js`:
```javascript
async rewrites() {
  return [{ source: '/api/:path*', destination: 'https://external-api.com/:path*' }];
}
```
Now call `/api/endpoint` instead of `https://external-api.com/endpoint`. The server-to-server request has no CORS.

**Common mistakes:**
- Adding CORS headers on the CLIENT fetch — does nothing, CORS is server-side
- Using `mode: 'no-cors'` on fetch — this silently returns an opaque response you can't read, doesn't solve anything
- Adding headers to the request hoping the server will accept them — the server must explicitly allow them

Check your browser's Network tab → click the failed request → look at the Response headers. If there's no `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header, the server isn't configured for CORS.

The page flickers/flashes white before dark mode loads

This is FOUC (Flash of Unstyled Content). The browser renders the page with default (light) styles before your JavaScript sets the dark theme.

**Root cause:** The theme is set by JavaScript, which runs AFTER the first paint.

**Fix: Use a blocking inline script in `<head>`:**
```html
<head>
  <script>
    // This runs BEFORE the page renders
    const theme = localStorage.getItem('theme') || 
      (window.matchMedia('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)').matches ? 'dark' : 'light');
    document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', theme);
  </script>
  <style>
    /* Default to dark to prevent flash */
    :root { --bg: #0e0e14; }
    [data-theme="light"] { --bg: #f8f8fa; }
  </style>
</head>
```

Key principles:
- The script must be in `<head>`, NOT at end of body, NOT `defer`, NOT `async`
- It must be inline (not an external file) so there's no network delay
- It reads localStorage synchronously before first paint
- The CSS should default to dark (most common preference) so the flash is light→dark only for light-theme users, which is less noticeable

If you're using Next.js, the same principle applies — set the cookie/attribute server-side or in a `<Script strategy="beforeInteractive">` tag.

My Tailwind classes aren't being applied

Three common causes:

**1. Tailwind isn't scanning your file:**
Check `tailwind.config.js` — the `content` array must include your file paths:
```javascript
module.exports = {
  content: [
    './src/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}',  // Must match your file structure
    './app/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}',
    './pages/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}',
  ],
}
```
If your file is outside these paths, Tailwind won't generate the classes.

**2. Class name is dynamically constructed:**
```jsx
// BAD — Tailwind can't detect dynamic class names at build time
const color = 'red';
<div className={`bg-${color}-500`}>  // Tailwind doesn't see 'bg-red-500'

// GOOD — use complete class names
const colorClass = isError ? 'bg-red-500' : 'bg-green-500';
<div className={colorClass}>  // Tailwind sees both full strings
```

What's the event loop in JavaScript?

JavaScript is single-threaded but non-blocking. The event loop is how it handles async operations without freezing.

**The model:**
1. **Call stack** — where synchronous code runs, one function at a time
2. **Web APIs** — browser handles setTimeout, fetch, DOM events off the main thread
3. **Callback queue** — completed async callbacks wait here
4. **Event loop** — checks: is the call stack empty? If yes, move the next callback from the queue to the stack

**Example:**
```javascript
console.log('1');
setTimeout(() => console.log('2'), 0);
console.log('3');
// Output: 1, 3, 2
```

Even with 0ms delay, setTimeout goes to the Web API → callback queue → waits for stack to clear → then runs. So '3' prints before '2'.

**Microtasks vs Macrotasks:**
Promises use the microtask queue, which has HIGHER priority than setTimeout's macrotask queue:
```javascript
console.log('1');
setTimeout(() => console.log('2'), 0);       // macrotask
Promise.resolve().then(() => console.log('3')); // microtask
console.log('4');
// Output: 1, 4, 3, 2
```
Microtasks (promises) run before macrotasks (setTimeout) after the current stack clears.

**Why this matters:**
- Long synchronous operations block the event loop → UI freezes
- `await` doesn't block — it yields to the event loop and resumes later
- requestAnimationFrame runs before the next paint (better than setTimeout for animations)
- Never do heavy computation in the main thread — use Web Workers

Specificity determines which CSS rule wins when multiple rules target the same element. It's a point system.

**The hierarchy (highest to lowest):**
1. `!important` — nuclear option, overrides everything
2. Inline styles (`style="..."`) — 1000 points
3. IDs (`#header`) — 100 points
4. Classes, attributes, pseudo-classes (`.card`, `[type="text"]`, `:hover`) — 10 points
5. Elements, pseudo-elements (`div`, `p`, `::before`) — 1 point
6. Universal (`*`) — 0 points

**Calculation:**
```css
p { }                    /* 0-0-1 (one element) */
.card { }                /* 0-1-0 (one class) */
#header { }              /* 1-0-0 (one ID) */
.card .title { }         /* 0-2-0 (two classes... wait no: 0-1-1 — one class + one element) */
```

Wait, let me correct: `.card .title` = 0-1-0 + 0-0-1 = 0-1-1. Two selectors, different weight.

1. Why your class isn't overriding:
```css

```

2. Why you can't override a framework:
```css

/* Your CSS: */ .my-btn { background: red; }             /* 0-1-0 — loses */

```

**Best practices:**
- Use classes for everything (flat specificity, easy to override)
- Avoid IDs in CSS (too specific, hard to override)
- Never use `!important` unless overriding third-party CSS you can't edit
- `:where()` has zero specificity — useful for resets/defaults
- Order matters only when specificity is EQUAL (later rule wins)

I'm getting 'z-index not working' error

z-index only works on positioned elements AND within the same stacking context.

**Check 1:** Is the element positioned? `z-index` does nothing on `position: static` (default). Add `position: relative/absolute/fixed`.

**Fix:** Move the element (modal/dropdown) to root level DOM, or use a React portal. Don't nest high-z-index elements inside low-z-index parents.
